Yes, the technology being used to track and observe hyenas in the Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park is indeed fascinating. The researchers from the University of Pretoria are using GPS collars and camera traps to gather data on the hyenas.

GPS collars are attached to individual hyenas, which allow the researchers to track their movements and observe their behavior. The collars are designed to collect location data at regular intervals, and this information is transmitted to the researchers via satellite. By analyzing the GPS data, the researchers can identify key habitats and movement patterns of the hyenas.

In addition to GPS collars, the researchers are also using camera traps to observe the hyenas in their natural habitat. Camera traps are motion-activated cameras that capture images of the hyenas as they move through the park. The cameras are strategically placed in areas where the hyenas are known to frequent, and this allows the researchers to observe their behavior and interactions with each other.

By using these advanced technologies, the researchers are able to gain unprecedented insights into the social behavior of the hyenas. The data collected from GPS collars and camera traps can be analyzed to reveal patterns of movement, social structure, and vocal communication among the hyenas. This information is helping the researchers develop a better understanding of the social dynamics of these animals and develop effective conservation strategies to protect their populations in the park.
